column2: Potential Indirect (Enablers or Proxies) Corelating Data Points
Active mobile money accounts per 1,000 adults
column4: Activity (not just registration) captures real usage and stickiness of DFS. FAS tracks registered vs. active accounts.
Signals mainstreamization of digital tools and deeper usage beyond account opening. Ethiopia’s usage lags peers, important for targeting.
Signals the extent of redudancies in Agent activities accross different locations

column2: Registered mobile money accounts per 1,000 adults
column4: Measures access and market reach of mobile money services. High registration signals availability.

column2: Percentage of adults with a digital financial account
column4: Captures formal financial inclusion, including banks and mobile money.

column2: Average digital transactions per active user per month
column4: Reflects depth of usage and customer engagement, not just access. Higher frequency indicates habit formation, trust, and product relevance.

column2: Mobile money transaction volume per capita
column4: Shows how intensively digital finance is used across the population

column2: Mobile money transaction value per capita
column4: Complements transaction volume by capturing economic significance, not just frequency.

column2: Percentage of P2P transfers per digital transactions
column4: Indicates whether DFS usage is narrow (mainly remittances) or diversified. High P2P dominance can signal early-stage ecosystems, while declining shares suggest growth in merchant, bill, and government payments.
Measures physical acceptance infrastructure for digital payments.
Tracks low-cost, scalable merchant acceptance, especially important in low-income and informal markets.
Shows two-sided market health. Without merchant acceptance, consumer adoption stacks; this metric reflects real opportunities to spend digitally, not just send money.
Signals cash-in/cash-out access and the strength of the legacy banking interface.
Reflects traditional financial infrastructure depth. Important for understanding geographic access gaps, cost structures, and where digital channels must compensate for limited physical presence.
Measures the inclusion impact of mobile money beyond banks.
